A four-month-old baby boy was shaken so severely by his dad that he was left permanently brain damaged and will need nursing care for the rest of his life, a court has heard. 
Zsolt Lakatos admits that he shook the infant on two separate occasions but denies that he had intended to cause him serious harm. 
He previously told interviewers he had shaken the child vigorously "in a moment of frustration." 
Neville Biddle, prosecuting, said when Lakatos, known as George, was interviewed by police he was “ducking and weaving and trying to avoid questions and frequently not telling the truth”. 
Eventually he admitted he had shaken the infant on two occasions, causing the serious injuries he suffered, the Liverpool Echo reports. 
But he maintained he had not intended to cause such harm. 
Lakatos, 31, of Walton, is on trial at Liverpool Crown Court where he denies unlawfully and malicious causing grievous bodily harm to the boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, with intent on September 2, 2015. 
He has pleaded guilty to two lesser charges of causing grievous bodily harm to the child on September 2 and on an earlier occasion. Zsolt Lakatos, also known as George Lakatos, 31, leaving Liverpool Crown court (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
Mr Biddle said that the baby was born on April 20, 2015, and lived with his mum in Walton. 
When given a routine check by his GP on August 28 that year, there was no sign of injury or distress. 
At about 2pm on September 2 a neighbour, Christine Morton, was arriving home by taxi when she saw the baby’s mum in the street holding his limp body and shouting for help. 
She began mouth to mouth resuscitation and CPR while the mum and Lakatos called an ambulance. 
Mr Biddle said: “After a while the baby spluttered and milk came out of his nose and she detected a faint pulse.” 
Paramedics arrived and he was given oxygen and CPR before being taken to Alder Hey Hospital where he was intubated and anaesthetised. 
Mr Biddle said: “A CT scan showed bilateral subdural haemorrhages between the skull and surface of the brain.” 
The court heard that some of the bleeding on the brain had happened within the previous three hours and some was older. 
The boy had also suffered a recent fracture to his right shin bone and had four rib fractures dating from an earlier incident. 
He had also suffered haemorrhages in his eyes. (Photo: MEN) 
He needed intensive care and had to undergo surgery to remove fluid because of a brain haemorrhage. 
Mr Biddle told the jurors: “He suffered permanent injury and will require nursing care for the rest of his life.” 
In his police interviews, Lakatos denied deliberately causing him injury. 
He said that afterwards he had been “praying all day and crying”. 
He denied hitting the baby or causing the rib fractures. 
The court heard that doctors believe the fractured shin, near his right knee, could have been caused while flailing around while being shaken but was more likely to have been caused by a “yanking” or “twisting” motion. 
Lakatos was interviewed for the fourth time in March last year after he had made admissions about shaking the tot during family proceedings, said Mr Biddle. 
At that hearing he admitted “in a moment of frustration I shook him vigorously”. 
Lakatos said he had not wanted him to become unconscious and had tried to revive him. 
In earlier interviews he told how he had been holding the crying child in his arms while feeding him a bottle. 
He said: “I didn’t mean to hurt him on either occasion. I had no idea after the first occasion that anything was wrong with him.” Like us on Facebook
